DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Fighting In Panama Between U.S.-Panamanian Troops
LEADS with 15 grafs with details of fighting; Picks up 16th pvs, `A U.S. ...'
DOC.TEXT: Machine-gun and cannon fire resounded through the capital Tuesday night as U.S. tanks and truckloads of American troops headed toward Panama's military headquarters in an apparent bid to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The Panamanian leader had said Friday that Panama was in a ``state of war'' with the United States and the following day a U.S. Marine lieutenant was killed by Panamanians in what American officials called an unprovoked attack. U.S. troops in Panama have been on maximum alert since and on Monday a U.S. military officer wounded a Panamanian police officer in what he said was self-defense. An Associated Press reporter saw 24 U.S. tanks and at least four trucks carrying American troops head in the direction of Panamanian Defense Forces headquarters on Tuesday night. Troops in olive uniforms ran through the luxury Marriott Hotel and lights in the hotel went out. Channel 8, television station of the U.S. Southern Command, issued an Echo level alert, its highest, and said movement by unauthorized U.S. personnel was prohibited. The roar of planes and helicopters were heard over the city. Earlier Tuesday, Panama accused the U.S. forces of violating its air space with ``observation planes and helicopters'' in preparation for military action. Frequent movements of U.S. soldiers and equipment have been seen within U.S. military installations the past three days, and appeared to escalate Tuesday at Howard Air Force Base. About 12,000 American soldiers are stationed along the Panama Canal. The United States has tried to oust Noriega, who controls the Panamanian military and the country, since he was indicted on federal drug trafficking charges in February 1988. U.S. sanctions have depressed the economy, but have not budged Noriega, and two coup attempts _ most recently in October _ failed to unseat him. An NBC News broadcast Tuesday showed what it said were C-141 Starlifter transport planes landing in Panama in the afternoon. It said one plane was landing every 10 minutes and that security had been tightened around the air base. Later Tuesday, a New York Times reporter and a Reuters reporter were detained for about an hour by U.S. military police when they tried to enter Howard air base to determine whether U.S. forces were landing. The Times reporter's notebooks were confiscated by the U.S. Army, the Times said in New York, and the two reporters were released without incident. An AP reporter who drove through Howard air base Tuesday night saw at least 10 large transport planes, an unusually high number. There also were six to eight helicopters parked there, in contrast to the usual three or four. It was not clear what kind of planes they were or whether they transported troops or cargo. A U.S. Southern Command spokesman said earlier Tuesday ``no unusual military activity'' was taking place. Later he said he knew nothing about the reported arrival of C-141 planes. At Fort Clayton, headquarters of the U.S. Army South, tanks were pulled into a circle in an open area and troops climbed on and off them in routine cleaning and exercises Tuesday afternoon. Trucks and armored personnel carriers also were moved into public view. Telephone lines to the Southern Command offices at Quarry Heights and to officers' homes were busy late Tuesday. Access to Quarry Heights is limited, but a public road goes through Howard. Earlier Tuesday, C-141 planes were seen in the air around Fort Bragg, N.C., home of the Army's 82nd Airborne division. It was not known if they were connected to any U.S. military activity in Panama. Fort Bragg spokesmen would say only that Army units there were taking part in a routine ``emergency deployment readiness exercise.'' Sgt. Bobby Feibel, a spokesman for the division, said he had no information on reports that some of the division had left Fort Bragg. In California, soldiers of the 7th Infantry Division (Light) were mobilized Monday at Fort Ord Army base, also for a readiness exercise, said base public affairs officer Jim Davis. ``As a matter of policy, we do not address destination, unit size, unit designation, or times of departure,'' Davis added. Lt. Pascual Gonzalez, director of civil aviation, said Panama has ``a critical situation'' with the United States. ``We think the level of aggression and intimidation will increase,'' he told The Associated Press. ``There are helicopters flying during the night over our installations,'' he said. At the State Department in Washington, spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Noriega's declaration last week that a state of war existed with the United States, followed by ``indiscriminate and unprovoked violence against Americans, clearly increases tensions in Panma.'' Ms. Tutwiler would not say what contingencies or options were under consideration. Panamanian officials say the American officer was killed when he and three others drove a car past checkpoints, then fired at Noriega's military headquarters building, wounding two civilians and a soldier. The United States says the four were unarmed, in civilian clothes, when they got lost near the headquarters. Lt. Robert Paz, 25, who had been in Panama since September, was killed when the group fled civilians and soldiers who tried to force them from their car at the checkpoint, Southern Command said. On Monday, a U.S. Army officer wounded a Panamanian police corporal because he thought the man was about to draw a weapon, according to Southern Command. Police Cpl. Cesar Tejada, who was shot once in the left arm, told journalists permitted to interview him in a hospital Tuesday the American had initiated the incident. ``I was merely standing there, doing my job, when this car went by at high speed and the driver fired two shots at me,'' he said. ``I never gave him a reason for it.'' Journalists also were permitted to interview another patient, Alex Correa, who said he belonged to the security detail at military headquarters. Correa said he was shot in the arm Saturday by the Americans. Southern Command officials have said repeatedly the only shooting was by Panamanian troops. Noriega has denied the drug charges.
